title: Liberal senator Dean Smith calls for GST to be raised from 10 per cent to 12.5 per cent
text:
The GST could be raised beyond its present level of 10 per cent so housing investors are spared from having to pay property tax.

Liberal senator Dean Smith wants the Goods and Services tax increased to 12.5 per cent so inefficient charges like payroll tax can be replaced.

His call was made several days after New South Wales Treasurer Dominic Perrottet called for the GST to be be broadened, to include fresh fruit and vegetables, so the states could be compensated to abolish property stamp duty.

The GST could be raised beyond its present level of 10 per cent so housing investors are spared from having to pay property tax. Liberal senator Dean Smith wants the Goods and Services tax increased to 12.5 per cent so inefficient charges like payroll tax can be replaced

Under current arrangements, someone buying a typical suburban house in Sydney has to pay $40,000, or half a year's average salary, upfront if they buy a $1million house in a middle-distance suburb.

Stamp duty accounts for eight per cent of NSW's $84.3billion in revenue.

The GST has remained at 10 per cent since it debuted in July 2000 ahead of the Sydney Olympics.

Senator Smith, however, wants it raised so state governments are given funds to abolish payroll tax on employers who take on new staff.

'Compensating state and territories for lost revenue could be achieved by broadening the GST or by a modest (but politically courageous) lift in the GST from 10 to 12.5 per cent,' he said in a column for The Australian Financial Review on Monday.

His Liberal colleague Tim Wilson, who chairs the parliamentary economics committee, said Senator Smith's proposal would fail to stop the states from complaining as the federal government collected more GST to redistribute.

His call was made several days after New South Wales Treasurer Dominic Perrottet called for the GST to be be broadened, to include fresh fruit and vegetables, so the states could be compensated to abolish property stamp duty (pictured is aun action at Blacktown in Sydney's west)

He told Daily Mail Australia this proposal would make the states 'unaccountable for the revenue they spend' even though 'all the revenue's collected by the federal government'.

'It leaves us in a situation where we're collecting more money and then the states aren't responsible,' he said.

'They just buck pass it all to the federal government.'

The Institute of Public Affairs, a free market think tank Mr Wilson worked for as a policy director before being elected to Parliament, is in favour of allowing the states to collect their own GST.

The IPA also wants the states to be able to set their own GST rather than relying on the federal government to redistribute the money back to them via the Commonwealth Grants Commission.
description: Liberal senator Dean Smith wants the Goods and Services tax increased to 12.5 per cent so inefficient charges like payroll tax can be replaced.
authors: Stephen Johnson For Daily Mail Australia
